A Bulwark/Triad essay arguing that the central risk from AI may be **speed**: rapid adoption could create a macroeconomic shock (job displacement → reduced consumption → cascading demand collapse) that complex social/economic systems may not adapt to quickly.

It also emphasizes that society can choose **regulatory constraints** on where/when machine labor is permitted—i.e., “we have agency,” and don’t have to accept a dystopian default.
